title: Stoke manager Mark Hughes reveals he tried to sign Chelsea captain John Terry
text:
Sport Stoke manager Mark Hughes reveals he tried to sign Chelsea captain John Terry Terry will end his Chelsea career this summer after two decades at his only club, winning four Premier League titles, four FA Cups, three League Cups and the Champions League Share Stoke made an approach for John Terry (Photo: AFP/Getty Images)     
Mark Hughes approached John Terry to discuss a move to Stoke City. 
But the Potters chief admitted Bruno Martins Indi’s permanent switch has scuppered the deal. 
Terry, 36, will end his Chelsea career this summer after two decades at his only club, winning four Premier League titles, four FA Cups, three League Cups and the Champions League. 
Hughes starred for the Blues when Terry was a youngster at Stamford Bridge and the Welshman was interested in extending the former England captain’s career. 
But the City boss admits the chances are unlikely now as Martins Indi, 25, is set to make his loan from Porto permanent. 
Hughes said: “I played with John when he was just starting off, and it was a conversation after the Chelsea game [in late December] in terms of what he’s going to do. Terry in action in the FA Cup (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
“You’d imagine he’s looking to have one or two seasons where he’s playing regularly. So you look for opportunities that will give him that. 
“We have gone a long way down the line with Bruno, and when you’re contracting players, that really impacts on whether you’re going to pursue anybody else.” 
Stoke have agreed a fee of £8.7million to make Martins Indi’s loan permanent. 
Hughes said: “Our focus is trying to get Bruno signed and sealed. The fee’s agreed. There’s the will and hope from all sides to get it done and we’re very close.” Like us on Facebook
